body.body: Dissolve phospholipids in chloroform \(dehydrated with molecular sieves) to a final concentration of 20 mM.
Dispense the lipid solution into glass test tubes \(50 μL per tube).
Place the test tubes in a vacuum desiccator.
Evacuate overnight at room temperature in the dark to completely remove chloroform \(Fig. 1a).

Store lipid dry films in a vacuum desiccator at room temperature in the dark. The lipid dry films should be used within 1 month.
  


Tips: Phospholipids should be stored at −20 °C under a nitrogen atmosphere in the dark.
Mix mineral oil by gentle inversion just before use.
Collect a lipid dry film sample from a vacuum desiccator.
Place 1 mL of mineral oil into the glass test tube.
Seal the top of the tube with a heat-resistant sealing film \(Fig. 1b).
Incubate the tube at 80 °C for ~15 min in a dry bath incubator.
Dissolve the lipid dry film by vortexing \(~10 s; Fig. 1c).
If the lipid dry film remains at the bottom of the tube, repeat steps 10 and
Set the tube in a floating rack and float in a water bath sonicator.
Sonicate the tube for 90 min at 60 °C and 60 W power \(Fig. 1d).
Immediately after sonication, mix the lipid-oil mixture by vortexing \(~10 s).
Cool to room temperature and incubate overnight at room temperature in the dark.
The concentration of lipids in oil is 1 mM. Store the lipid-oil mixture at room temperature in the dark, and use within 1 week of preparation.
Place two pieces of double-sided adhesive tape \(thickness: <sub>100 μm) onto a silicone-coated coverslip with a </sub>8 mm gap between them.
Place a normal coverslip on top of the gap, to produce a chamber of 18 mm × 8 mm × 100 μm \(see Fig. 2c).
Mix lipid-oil mixture by vortexing immediately before use.
Transfer 80 μL of the lipid-oil mixture into a 1.5-mL microcentrifuge tube pre-equilibrated to a desired temperature.
Pipet 2 μL of protein solution directly into the lipid-oil mixture in the microcentrifuge tube \(Fig. 2a).

Mix the lipid-oil mixture and protein solutions by vortexing for 10–30 s to form water-in-oil droplets \(Fig. 2b). The droplet size can be controlled by optimizing the power and duration of vortexing.
Perfuse the water-in-oil emulsion into a flow chamber \(Fig. 2c).
Seal the flow chamber with Valap \(Fig. 2d).
Observe the water-in-oil droplets using an optical microscope \(Fig. 3).
